Award.AwardTitle: US Travel Support for IHP Trimester in Probability
Award.AbstractNarration:
This travel grant provides support for US researchers participating in the Institute Henri Poincar√© Trimester in Probability titled "Disordered Systems, Random Spatial Processes, and Some Applications." The trimester comprises four conferences that will take place between January and April 2015. Hard sciences such as mathematics and physics thrive on unsolved old and new problems. They have recently been called to focus on matters traditionally away from their realm, for instance on questions arising from socio-economic investigations. This situation presents a new opportunity for growth of the fields. This set of meetings provides a venue for a range of scientific communities to discuss these sometimes-controversial topics, toward development of a common and well-grounded scientific understanding. The two research areas of disordered systems and random spatial processes have developed in recent years the methodological and conceptual skills to approach these new applications.

The trimester concerns studies of random spatial processes, disordered systems, and applications to socio-economic sciences. Spatial probability is concerned with the investigation of large-scale random structures extended in space-time. Disordered systems are a natural setting to describe phenomena with multiple equilibrium states, a situation that now appears to be the norm rather than an exception. Regarding applications to socio-economic systems, the main theme will be strongly interacting agent based models, which are extensions of the McFadden Discrete Choice theory (Nobel Prize in Economy, 2000). Specific models to be discussed include: Polymer models and self-interacting walks; random walks in a (dynamically evolving) random environment; two-dimensional models scaling to stochastic Loewner evolution; random graphs, from the simple Poissonian degree distribution to the scale-free; the Sherrington-Kirkpatrick model; the Edwards-Anderson model; branching/coagulation processes; directed polymers in random environment in 1+1 dimensions; and the Kardar-Parisi-Zhang (KPZ) universality class.

The program website is http://www.ihp.fr/en/CEB/T1-2015

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of the project was to support a sequence of conferences at the Institute Henri Poincare in Paris, France. These were called a thematic "IHP Trimester in Probability." The title of this trimester was: Disordered Systems, Random Spatial Processes and Some Applications.
There were 4 conferences in this trimester.• Introductory School, January 5th - 9th CIRM, Marseille.• Statistical Physics Methods in Social and Economic Systems, January 26th to 30th, Institute HenriPoincare, Paris. ´• Spin Glasses, Random Graphs and Percolation, February 16th to 20th, IHP, Paris.• Interacting Particles Systems and Non-equilibrium Dynamics, March 9th to 13th, IHP, Paris
The IHP trimester in 2015 was funded by scientific agencies in France and the European Union.
We requested funding for travel support for young researchers from the US to attend the conferences and trimester.
Hard sciences like mathematics and physics strive on old and new problems. The trimester was supposed to provide a cultural background for all the scientific communities involved. It was expected that there would be cross-fertilization and mutual exchange of scientific approaches by physicists and social scientists as well as mathematicians.
This type of activity is particularly important for young researchers, who need some incentives and opportunities to learn to work across disciplines.
Our goal was to make sure that there would be an opportunity for young people to participate in all these conferences. 
The trimester at the IHP did convene all the listed conferences.
• Introductory School, January 5th - 9th CIRM, Marseille.• Statistical Physics Methods in Social and Economic Systems, January 26th to 30th, Institute HenriPoincare, Paris. ´• Spin Glasses, Random Graphs and Percolation, February 16th to 20th, IHP, Paris.• Interacting Particles Systems and Non-equilibrium Dynamics, March 9th to 13th, IHP, Paris
The website for the conference is 
http://www.ihp.fr/en/CEB/T1-2015
There were over 160 senior participants and many additional junior participants. The list of the senior participants may be found on the conference website
http://www.ihp.fr/en/CEB/T1-2015#jTab3


We had 26 participants from the US who were being funded by this grant to participate in one or more conferences.
Arguin Louis-PierreAuffinger AntonioBen Arous GérardChen Wai-KaiCorwin IvanDamron MichaelDembo AmirDostoglou StamatisFaris WilliamGold JulianJagannath AukoshKhandwawala MustafaKistler Nicola Kosygina ElenaLanoue DanielLebowitz JoëlLi XiangPanchenko DmitrySmerlak MatteoStarr ShannonStein DanielTayyab NawazVespignani AlessandroWalters MegWu WeiNewman CharlesRedner SidneyThese participants conveyed that they benefited substantially, and were grateful to the NSF for the support. We actually anticipated more participants requesting funding than that. We did advertise as broadly as possible.

Our specific objectives were to encourage participation in the IHP thematic trimester by as many junior researchers as possible. If one counts pre-tenure participants as junior, then there were 16, which was about 2/3 of those receiving support. Also 7 were graduate students or 1st year postdocs, which was about 1/3 of those receiving support. Several of the graduate students personally conveyed their gratitude to the NSF. 
Our goal was to make sure that there would be an opportunity for young people to participate in all these conferences. Two young researchers who attested that their research benefited from the conference were Julian Gold and Aukosh Jagannath. Both claimed to have written substantial parts of their PhD thesis or a journal article thanks in part to the conference. They received support to attend the conference due to this grant.
Participating in 1 or more of these conference could be considered professional development, especially for the 7 graduate student participants. The first conference was the Introductory School, January 5th - 9th CIRM, Marseille. This conference was specifically targeted at graduate students. One of the participants who was supported was L-P Arguin. He gave a series of lectures to provide a pedagogical introduction to the topics of the conference. Several students have indicated that the time at the IHP did help them in their graduate studies.
There is a volume forthcoming about the topics of the conference, edited by two of the conference organizers: Cristian Giardina and Pierluigi Contucci. It is currently in the editing phase of publication. But it has not yet appeared. Several of the main speakers wrote review articles summarizing their talks. They will appear there. Some of the authors also posted their articles to the arXiv. For example, L-P Arguin's contribution is:http://arxiv.org/abs/1601.00582Extrema of log-correlated random variables: Principles and ExamplesThis is an excellent resource for newcomers to the field. It will be a pedagogical tool for years to come.
